author: JENELLE JANCI | Staff Writer
title: Amy Robach, to speak at Pink: A Women's Event, recounts breast cancer battle in new book
text:
Press photo 
News anchor Amy Robach is a breast cancer survivor. She will speak at October's PINK event. 
During one of the most harrowing periods of her life, Amy Robach wasn't afforded the privilege of privacy. 
The "Good Morning America" news co-anchor agreed to receive a mammogram on air for a Breast Cancer Awareness Month segment. She was convinced to do so by producers and her fellow anchor, breast cancer survivor Robin Roberts. 
Roberts told Robach that if the segment saved just one life, it would be worth it. 
On Oct. 1, 2013, Robach had a mammogram on live television. After completing follow-up tests, she announced Nov. 11, 2013, on television that she had breast cancer. Robach was 40 when she was diagnosed. Related Tim Gunn says fashion career chose him; will speak Oct. 3 at Pink: A Women's Event 
Tim Gunn has plenty to say about the state of fashion today, and he'll share his views at Pink: A Women's Event Oct. 3 in Lancaster. What he doesn't like is people buying trendy clothes for the sake of a trend. 
Public service 
"I did not realize it was going to be as personal as it was," Robach told Variety magazine. "When I agreed to the mammogram, I was convinced to by producers and by Robin (Roberts), and it was a public service that ended up saving my life." 
Robach will speak at PINK: A Women's Event, a showcase produced by LNP and sponsored by Lancaster General Health. 
Robach underwent a double mastectomy, breast reconstruction and eight rounds of chemotherapy to fight the disease. She told People magazine that she's taking tamoxifen during her recovery to prevent the cancer from returning. She'll be on the drug for 10 years. 
Robach recounts her diagnosis and treatment in her new book, "Better," released Sept. 29. 
Robach's #GIRLPOWER series on "GMA" features influential and inspiring women. She occasionally appears on “20/20.” Prior to her work with ABC News, Robach worked for NBC as an anchor on "Today Weekend" and as a correspondent for "Today." If You Go: 
• What: Pink: A Women’s Event, showcasing the latest in health, fashion, wellness, food, books and more. 
• When: 2-7 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 3. 
• Where: Lancaster County Convention Center, 25 S. Queen St. 
• Schedule: Speakers Tim Gunn, 2:30 p.m., Amy Robach, 5:30 p.m.; fashion show, 3:30 p.m.; Lancaster General Health breakout session, 4:30 p.m. 
• Tickets: $15 in advance; $20 at the door. If you o rder online , there's a $1.74 fee added. VIP admission (includes brunch with Tim Gunn), $150 plus $8.49 fee.
